Issues.Title: The SplitContainer control smarttag item “Horizontal Splitter Orientation" has an extra '.'
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

main branch of WinForms repo

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Not tested/verified

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

No, also repro in release/8.0 branch

### Issue description

Actual result: The SplitContainer control smarttag item “Horizontal Splitter Orientation" has an extra '.'.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/640516c8-d58f-45f2-9108-c477d014bd3f)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/abb3e7e6-a668-43fb-9b45-84d260d5c80d)

Expected result: The SplitContainer control smarttag item “Horizontal Splitter Orientation" should not contain '.'.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b3271f2a-844a-4dec-8041-3a9211e47f6c)

### Steps to reproduce

Test sample: [DemoConsole](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/tree/main/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/IntegrationTests/DesignSurface/DemoConsole) bases on main branch in Winforms repo.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The SplitContainer control smarttag item “Horizontal Splitter Orientation" has an extra '.'" (#12983)

Issues.Title: Exception pops up when moving the mouse wheel up or down in ShortcutKeys property
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 10 SDK build: 10.0.100-preview.2.25118.3

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, cannot repro in .NET 6.0/7.0, regression from .NET 8.0

### Issue description

Exception pops up when moving the mouse wheel up or down in ShortcutKeys property. Repro in .NET 10/9/8, cannot in .NET6/7

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eaf6277b-5208-489b-a100-b6682c07fe42)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0631f645-38ce-4e0e-bc73-519442952210

**Debug log:**
System.ComponentModel.InvalidEnumArgumentException
  HResult=0x80070057
  Message=The value of argument 'value' (65536) is invalid for Enum type 'Keys'. (Parameter 'value')
  Source=System.Windows.Forms
  StackTrace:
   at System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.set_ShortcutKeys(Keys value) in C:\Users\v-olzhan\source\repos\winforms\src\System.Windows.Forms\src\System\Windows\Forms\Controls\ToolStrips\ToolStripMenuItem.cs:line 365
   at System.Reflection.MethodBaseInvoker.InvokeWithOneArg(Object obj, BindingFlags invokeAttr, Binder binder, Object[] parameters, CultureInfo culture)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a Winforms .NET application with menuStrip and propertyGrid controls added
2. Add a toolStripMenuItem1 in menuStrip
3. Set propertyGrid's SelectedObject to toolStripMenuItem1
4. Build and run application
5. Find ShortcutKeys property in propertyGrid, click `(None)` value, then move the mouse wheel up or down
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Exception pops up when moving the mouse wheel up or down in ShortcutKeys property" (#12982)

Issues.Title: The designer icon never appears in the Solution Explorer tab (the path spaces issue)
Issues.Body:
### Environment

Visual Studio 17.13.0

### .NET version

.NET 9

### Did this work in a previous version of Visual Studio and/or previous .NET release?

Yes

### Issue description

Starting with the latest VS build it became impossible to show the visual designer, either by double clicking the file or using the context menu command. Note that the corresponding file association is still generated:
```xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Project ToolsVersion="Current" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003">
    <ItemGroup>
        <Compile Update="Form1.cs">
            <SubType>Form</SubType>
        </Compile>
    </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/88d1bc00-7edb-4d23-b3f3-202f069cc9c4)

### Steps to reproduce

Create a brand new WinForms (.NET) project on any path that contains **spaces** in it. E.g., 
`C:\Users\Admin\source\repos\New Folder (4)\WinFormsApp1\WinFormsApp1`

### Diagnostics

```text

```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "The designer icon never appears in the Solution Explorer tab (the path spaces issue)" (#12978)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Set stream copy position to beginning" (#12971)

Issues.Title: Ensure `ComManagedStream` seekable wrapper stream has position of 0 (…
Issues.Body:
…#12953)

PORTS #12953 - DO NOT SQUASH

Until .NET 5, `ComManagedStream` (then `GPStream`) would wrap a non-seekable stream in a `MemoryStream` using the `MemoryStream(Byte[])` constructor. This results in a stream with a position of 0.

dotnet/runtime commit 136527537e6 (Improve perfromance for loading from Stream on Windows (dotnet/corefx#31142), 2018-07-20) updated this logic to instead use `CopyTo` to populate the wrapping `MemoryStream`. This results in a stream with a non-zero position.

It seems that this non-zero position causes some issues in downstream code when using `Image.FromStream` to load `.emf` and `.wmf` files, resulting in `LoadGdipImageFromStream` returning a status of 2 and thus an exception.

Seek the wrapping `MemoryStream` back to the beginning after copying the source stream into it to prevent this exception.


 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12970)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Ensure `ComManagedStream` seekable wrapper stream has position of 0 (…" (#12970)

Issues.Title: Prevent Toolbar tooltips from appearing directly under cursor hotspot
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #12958


## Proposed changes

- This positions the `ToolTip` so that it is offset by 1px from the cursor's HotSpot X value.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- This prevents `ToolStrip` tooltips from appearing directly under cursor HotSpot. Thus, the user is able to click the `ToolStripItem`.

-

Issues.Title: ToolStrip tooltips can appear directly under cursor hotspot
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

9.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

When a `ToolStrip` is next to the Windows Taskbar, a `ToolStripItem`'s ToolTip can appear directly under cursor HotSpot. This prevents the item from being clicked.

This is an issue that has come up quite a few times over the years in the Paint.NET community.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/7de4679d-a027-4d8c-a7d8-fbaeb870186d)

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/0205147d-2041-4a8b-8896-5bd7a4e6dd73

cc: @rickbrew

### Steps to reproduce

1. Move a Form so that a ToolStrip is just above the Windows Taskbar.
2. Hover the mouse over a ToolStripItem until its ToolTip appears.
3. Try to click the ToolStripItem.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ToolStrip tooltips can appear directly under cursor hotspot" (#12958)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Update dependencies from dotnet/runtime" (#12957)

Issues.Title: Avoid ECMA spec violation in PropertyStore
Issues.Body:
The manual unboxing we were doing was not an ECMA approved use of the instruction. As such it could potentially fail in the future should the runtime decide to break the way we were using it.

One way to fix this would be to set each of the fields individually on the unboxed ref as the current two types we're optimizing are mutable. I've instead used `StrongBox<T>`. While significantly more complicated, it will not run afoul of the ECMA spec should we get an immutable type we want to handle.

If performance here ever ends up being a problem we could go the other way.

Fixes #12933
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/12956)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Avoid ECMA spec violation in PropertyStore" (#12956)

Issues.Title: React to NuGet package pruning warnings
Issues.Body:
Contributes to https://github.com/dotnet/sdk/pull/46829

NuGet added a new feature that automatically prunes package and project references that are provided by the shared framework that is targeted.

Resolve the warnings that got emitted when building the repository in non-source-only mode.
